title: 115_hr5018
content: The Act is titled the "Education and Workforce Innovation Act" and includes provisions for Community Workforce Training Grants. The "Education and Workforce Innovation Act" authorizes a pilot program to award grants for job training in high-demand industries. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant and use the funds to develop multi-year training programs for students. The "Education and Workforce Innovation Act" aims to provide students with education and training in high-growth industries, offering customized training, increased productivity, a pathway to high-quality employment, a successful model, and opportunities for career advancement. The "Education and Workforce Innovation Act" offers customized training in high-growth industries, career advancement opportunities, and covers program costs including overhead, program design, and tuition subsidies for students. Eligible entities must provide matching funds from non-Federal sources. An advisory panel will oversee the pilot program. The pilot program under the "Education and Workforce Innovation Act" will have an advisory panel of experts and executives. At least $50,000,000 will be available annually for the program's costs from the Workforce Innovation Fund. Eligible entities are private companies in manufacturing, production, or technology industries partnering with junior or community colleges, postsecondary vocational institutions, or secondary schools. The terms "junior or community college," "postsecondary vocational institution," "secondary school," and "skilled labor and trade industries" are defined in reference to specific sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "skilled labor and trade industries" will be defined by the Secretary of Labor. SEC. 3. FINANCING A SKILLED 21ST CENTURY WORKFORCE GOAL. The Secretaries of Education and the Treasury, along with an advisory panel, will run a pay-for-performance pilot program for 5 years to raise funds from investors for a training program that increases trade certifications or apprenticeships for unemployed or dislocated workers. The program must establish goals for increasing certifications, reducing training-related expenditures, and require qualified investors to participate. The Secretaries, along with an advisory panel, will implement a pay-for-performance program where qualified investors fund a training program for unemployed or dislocated workers. If the program meets set goals, the investors will be repaid. The Secretaries and an advisory panel will assess expanding the pay-for-performance pilot program on a larger scale. $75,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2019 to 2023. Definitions for "advisory panel," "dislocated worker," and "unemployed individual" are provided in the Act. The Innovation and Opportunity Act defines terms such as "qualified investor," "Secretaries," and "service provider" in relation to workforce training programs.
